abstract.text: A study of forward energy flow and central charged-particle multiplicity in events with W and Z bosons decaying into leptons is presented.
The analysis uses a sample of 7 TeV pp collisions, corresponding to an integrated luminosity of 36 pb −1 , recorded by the CMS experiment at the LHC.
The observed forward energy depositions, their correlations, and the central charged-particle multiplicities are not well described by the available non-diffractive soft-hadron production models.
A study of about 300 events with no significant energy deposited in one of the forward calorimeters, corresponding to a pseudorapidity gap of at least 1.9 units, is also presented.
An indication for a diffractive component in these events comes from the observation that the majority of the charged leptons from the W(Z) decays are found in the hemisphere opposite to the gap.

When fitting the signed lepton pseudorapidity distribution of these events with predicted distributions from an admixture of diffractive (POMPYT) and non-diffractive (PYTHIA) Monte Carlo simulations, the diffractive component is determined to be (50.0 ± 9.3 (stat.) ± 5.2 (syst.))%.

body_text.text: Introduction

At high energies, proton-proton reactions are generally described in terms of a two-component outgoing system, pp → XY , where X is a state originating from a perturbative parton-parton interaction and Y consists of proton remnants carrying a large fraction of the total energy.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The system Y represents the "underlying event" and consists of mostly low-transverse-momentum hadrons originating from parton showers, and non-perturbative multi-parton interactions.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The latter are largely independent of the hard inter- * e-mail: cms-publication-committee-chair@cern.ch action, increase the particle multiplicity, and lead to correlations between the energy flows in the central and forward regions.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The currently available models of multi-parton interactions have mainly been tuned to minimum-bias data and to final states including jets with large transverse momentum (p T ), using the observed central charged-particle multiplicities and the transverse momentum spectra of hadrons that are not associated with the hard jets.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Models for a detailed simulation of multi-parton interactions are under rapid development and new features, including diffractive components in the energy flow, are being extensively investigated.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: A recent detailed CMS study of the underlying event structure at central rapidities is given in [1].
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The analysis of the underlying event structure and energy flow correlations in hard processes with colorless final states, such as pp → W(Z)X → ν( )X, can provide insights into unexplored aspects of multi-parton interactions.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In particular, processes with colorless final states allow a straightforward separation of the hard interaction and the underlying event.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Correlations between the charged-particle multiplicity in the central rapidity range and energy depositions at large rapidities can give additional information about multi-parton interactions.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Furthermore, a fraction of these proton-proton interactions is expected to arise from single-diffractive (SD) reactions, where one of the colliding protons emerges intact from the interaction, having lost only a few percent of its energy.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Such SD events may be ascribed to the exchange of vacuum quantum numbers (often called Pomeron exchange), which leads to the absence of hadron production over a wide region of rapidity adjacent to the outgoing proton direction.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Experimentally, these large rapidity gaps will appear as regions of pseudorapidity devoid of detected particles.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Soft-diffractive events can be described in the framework of Regge theory (see, e.g., [2]).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Hard-diffractive events, with Fig. 1 Sketches of the process pp → W(Z)X, where a W(Z) boson is produced in the hard interaction, combined with contributions from multi-parton interactions, with and without a diffractive component.

body_text.text: The curly and straight lines are for gluons and quarks, respectively, unless indicated (W/Z).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The symbol P indicates the exchange of a state with the quantum numbers of the vacuum (Pomeron).

body_text.text: (a) shows the standard hard interaction;
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: (b) the same process with additional multi-parton interactions;
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: (c) the hard process accompanied by multi-parton interactions containing a diffractive component;
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: (d) the harddiffractive production of a W(Z) boson;
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: (f) the hard-diffractive W(Z) production with multi-parton interactions containing a diffractive component.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In the latter case, the diffractive component of the multi-parton interaction does not necessarily couple to the same proton as in the hard process (not shown here) the production of jets, heavy flavors, or W/Z bosons, have been observed at the SPS, HERA, and the Tevatron [3][4][5][6][7][8].
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: For electron-proton hard-diffractive interactions, a factorization theorem has been proven [9], allowing the introduc-tion of diffractive parton distribution functions (dPDFs).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In hadron-hadron diffractive interactions, factorization is however broken by soft multi-parton interactions [10,11], which fill the large rapidity gap and reduce the observed yields of hard-diffractive events.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Such interactions are not yet simulated in the currently available Monte Carlo (MC) generators, and the reduction in the large rapidity gap harddiffraction cross section is quantified by a suppression factor, the so-called rapidity gap survival probability.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: At the Tevatron, the observed hard-diffractive yields relative to the corresponding inclusive processes are approximately 1%.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: A recent study by CDF [12] indicates that the fractions of W and Z bosons produced diffractively are (1.00 ± 0.11)% and (0.88 ± 0.22)%, respectively.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The standard picture of W or Z boson production via hard parton-parton scattering is shown in Fig. 1a and combined with a multi-parton interaction in Fig. 1b.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: According to this picture, large rapidity gap events can only arise from multiplicity fluctuations.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Figure 1c shows standard W(Z) production accompanied by multi-parton interactions with a diffractive component.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Hard-diffractive production ( Fig. 1d) leads to a large rapidity gap.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Such contributions would result in almost unchanged central charged-particle multiplicity distributions with respect to Fig. 1b.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: However, a larger fraction of events with a relatively small energy deposition in the forward regions, and a smaller correlation of the energy flow in the central and forward regions, could be expected.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The diffractive production mechanism with multiparton interactions is shown in Fig. 1e.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In this case, large rapidity gap events only survive if the multi-parton component is small.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Finally, Fig. 1f indicates a possible combination of W(Z) production mechanisms with a diffractive component in both the hard process and the multi-parton interaction.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: This paper presents an analysis of the underlying event structure and of events with a pseudorapidity gap of more than 1.9 units (in the following, referred to as LRG events for simplicity) in the processes pp → WX and pp → ZX, in 7 TeV pp collisions at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC), and recorded in 2010 with the Compact Muon Solenoid (CMS) detector.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: A data sample corresponding to an integrated luminosity of 36 pb −1 has been analyzed.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Final states of the type WX and ZX are identified by the detection of electrons and muons with large transverse momentum p T .
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The underlying event structure is analyzed in terms of
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: (i) the chargedparticle multiplicity at central rapidities,
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: (ii) the forward energy flow, and
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: (iii) the correlations between these observables.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The observed LRG events are expected to be sensitive to a diffractive production component.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The paper is structured as follows: after giving a short description of the models for inclusive and diffractive vectorboson production in pp collisions (Sect. 2) and the CMS detector (Sect. 3), the selection of W and Z bosons with leptonic decays, the rejection of pileup events, and the energy measurement in the forward calorimeters are described in Sect.

Introduction

body_text.text: Section 5 summarizes the analysis of the underlying event structure in WX and ZX events in terms of the observed charged-particle multiplicity, the energy depositions in the forward calorimeters, and their correlations.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The analysis of events with a LRG signature is discussed in Sect.

body_text.text: Modeling of the underlying event structure in W and Z events

The simulation of non-diffractive processes, including multiple overlaid events within the same bunch crossing ("pileup"), was performed using the PYTHIA 6.420 and PYTHIA 8.145 event generators [13,14] with different tunes [15] for the underlying event structure and the multi-parton interactions.
body_text.section: Modeling of the underlying event structure in W and Z events

body_text.text: Several tunes were used for the simulation of the underlying event structure in W and Z events.
body_text.section: Modeling of the underlying event structure in W and Z events

body_text.text: In particular, the tunes developed before data from the LHC could be used were PYTHIA6 D6T [16], Pro-Q20 [17], Pro-PT0 [17], and P0 [18].
body_text.section: Modeling of the underlying event structure in W and Z events

body_text.text: The newer tunes PYTHIA6 Z2 [19] and the PYTHIA8 2C [20] include already some information from the LHC data.

body_text.text: The W and Z production cross sections were calculated using leading-order (LO) matrix elements for the process qq → W(Z), convolved with the CTEQ 6.6 parton distribution functions (PDFs) [21].

body_text.text: Experimental apparatus
A detailed description of the CMS experiment can be found elsewhere [25].
body_text.section: Experimental apparatus

body_text.text: The coordinate system has the origin at the nominal interaction point.
body_text.section: Experimental apparatus

body_text.text: The Z-axis is parallel to the anticlockwise beam direction; it defines the polar angle θ and the pseudorapidity η = − ln(tan(θ/2)).
body_text.section: Experimental apparatus

body_text.text: The azimuthal angle φ is measured in the plane transverse to the beam, from the direction pointing to the center of the LHC ring toward the upward direction.
body_text.section: Experimental apparatus

body_text.text: The central feature of the CMS apparatus is a superconducting solenoid, of 6 m internal diameter.
body_text.section: Experimental apparatus

body_text.text: Within the field volume are the silicon pixel and strip tracker, the crystal electromagnetic calorimeter (ECAL), and the brass scintillator hadronic calorimeter (HCAL).
body_text.section: Experimental apparatus

body_text.text: Muons are measured in gaseous detectors embedded in the steel return yoke.
body_text.section: Experimental apparatus

body_text.text: The ECAL, HCAL, and muon detectors are composed of barrel and endcap sections.
body_text.section: Experimental apparatus

body_text.text: The calorimeter cells are grouped in projective towers, of granularity η × φ = 0.087 × 0.087 radians at central rapidities.
body_text.section: Experimental apparatus

body_text.text: For forward rapidities the HCAL towers have a granularity of 0.174 radians in φ and are increasing as a function of η.
body_text.section: Experimental apparatus

body_text.text: Besides the barrel and endcap detectors, CMS has extensive forward calorimetry.
body_text.section: Experimental apparatus

body_text.text: The forward hadronic calorimeter (HF) consists of steel absorbers and embedded radiation-hard quartz fibers, which provide fast collection of Cherenkov light.
body_text.section: Experimental apparatus

body_text.text: The maximum pseudorapidity coverage is 2.9 < |η| < 5.2, but because of small differences in the passive material at large values of |η| between the real detector and the simulation, a fiducial coverage of 3.0 < |η| < 4.9 is used.
body_text.section: Experimental apparatus

body_text.text: Event selection procedure
Selection of W and Z events with decays to electrons and muons
The identification of W and Z bosons is based on the presence of isolated electrons and muons with high transverse momentum.
body_text.section: Selection of W and Z events with decays to electrons and muons

body_text.text: The selection criteria are given below.
body_text.section: Selection of W and Z events with decays to electrons and muons

body_text.text: A more detailed description of the lepton selection, the efficiencies, and the associated systematic uncertainties is given in [26].
body_text.section: Selection of W and Z events with decays to electrons and muons

body_text.text: Events are selected online by requiring a high-transversemomentum electron or muon with thresholds depending on the run period and varying between 10 and 17 GeV for electrons and between 9 and 15 GeV for muons.
body_text.section: Selection of W and Z events with decays to electrons and muons

body_text.text: Thus, a small fraction of W → τ ν or Z → τ τ events with leptonic decays of the τ is also included.
body_text.section: Selection of W and Z events with decays to electrons and muons

body_text.text: The trigger efficiency for signal events with the selection conditions defined below is above 99% [26].
body_text.section: Selection of W and Z events with decays to electrons and muons

body_text.text: The offline selection of electrons is based on the matching of a reconstructed high-transverse-momentum track candidate with energy depositions in the barrel and endcap calorimeters; shower shape requirements are applied to these clusters.
body_text.section: Selection of W and Z events with decays to electrons and muons

body_text.text: Electron candidates are required to have |η| < 2.5 and transverse momenta larger than 25 GeV.
body_text.section: Selection of W and Z events with decays to electrons and muons

body_text.text: Electrons from photon conversions are rejected.
body_text.section: Selection of W and Z events with decays to electrons and muons

body_text.text: In order to suppress background from jets, the electrons are required to be isolated using a cone in η − φ space around the electron direction with R < 0.3, where R = η 2 + φ 2 and η and φ are the pseudorapidity and azimuthal angle difference between the electron and jet directions.
body_text.section: Selection of W and Z events with decays to electrons and muons

body_text.text: The energy in the cone is calculated from the scalar sum of the transverse energies in the tracker and both calorimeters, and is required to be smaller than 10% of the lepton p T .
body_text.section: Selection of W and Z events with decays to electrons and muons

body_text.text: More details are given in Ref.
body_text.section: Selection of W and Z events with decays to electrons and muons
Selection of W and Z events with decays to electrons and muons

body_text.text: Two algorithms are used to identify muons.
body_text.section: Selection of W and Z events with decays to electrons and muons

body_text.text: One is based on the matching of a reconstructed high-transversemomentum silicon tracker candidate with a track candidate found in the muon system.
body_text.section: Selection of W and Z events with decays to electrons and muons

body_text.text: The second is based on a global fit to tracker and muon system hits.
body_text.section: Selection of W and Z events with decays to electrons and muons

body_text.text: Muons in this analysis have to pass both selection algorithms.
body_text.section: Selection of W and Z events with decays to electrons and muons

body_text.text: The reconstructed muon candidates are required to be at |η| < 2.5 and to have transverse momentum larger than 25 GeV.
body_text.section: Selection of W and Z events with decays to electrons and muons

body_text.text: The isolation criteria are similar to the ones used for electrons, and details about the muon identification are given in Ref.
body_text.section: Selection of W and Z events with decays to electrons and muons
Selection of W and Z events with decays to electrons and muons

body_text.text: Jets and the missing transverse momentum in the event are determined from the four-vectors of reconstructed particles, which are measured from the combination of the tracker and the calorimeter informations [27].
body_text.section: Selection of W and Z events with decays to electrons and muons

body_text.text: For jets, the anti-k t algorithm with a cone size of 0.5 is used [28].
body_text.section: Selection of W and Z events with decays to electrons and muons

body_text.text: The transverse momentum of jets is required to be larger than 30 GeV with a pseudorapidity of |η| < 2.5.
body_text.section: Selection of W and Z events with decays to electrons and muons

body_text.text: An event is selected as a W → ν candidate if the following requirements are satisfied: (1) one isolated electron or muon with a transverse momentum greater than 25 GeV and |η| < 1.4; events with a second isolated electron or muon with a transverse momentum above 10 GeV are rejected; (2) the missing transverse momentum (ascribed to the neutrino) greater than 30 GeV; (3) the transverse mass = 2E T (ν)E T ( ) − 2p T (ν) • p T ( ) of the charged lepton and the neutrino greater than 60 GeV.
body_text.section: Selection of W and Z events with decays to electrons and muons

body_text.text: Likewise, the following conditions are imposed to select Z(γ * ) → (called Z in the following) candidates: (1) two isolated electrons or muons with opposite charge and each with a minimum transverse momentum of 25 GeV; (2) at least one lepton with |η| < 1.4; (3) the reconstructed invariant mass of the dilepton system between 60 and 120 GeV.
body_text.section: Selection of W and Z events with decays to electrons and muons

body_text.text: This selection resulted into essentially background-free W and Z event samples.
body_text.section: Selection of W and Z events with decays to electrons and muons

body_text.text: The background for the W sample is estimated to be less than 1% and even smaller for the Z sample, independent of any additional requirements on the energies in the HF calorimeters.
body_text.section: Selection of W and Z events with decays to electrons and muons

body_text.text: The main features of the W and Z event samples are found to be insensitive to small variations of the selection criteria.
body_text.section: Selection of W and Z events with decays to electrons and muons

body_text.text: In the following, no efficiency corrections are applied, and only direct comparisons to MC predictions are shown.
body_text.section: Selection of W and Z events with decays to electrons and muons

body_text.text: Pileup rejection and single-vertex selection of W and Z events
As mentioned earlier, there can be several simultaneous pp interactions in the same bunch crossing in addition to the selected W and Z events, the so-called pileup.
body_text.section: Pileup rejection and single-vertex selection of W and Z events

body_text.text: As the number of bunches and the instantaneous luminosity increased steadily during the 2010 pp data taking, the analysis was affected by very different pileup conditions.
body_text.section: Pileup rejection and single-vertex selection of W and Z events

body_text.text: For this analysis the data have been separated into three periods (P) with average instantaneous luminosities of
body_text.section: Pileup rejection and single-vertex selection of W and Z events

body_text.text: , and L inst > 0.34 µb −1 /s (P III), respectively.
body_text.section: Pileup rejection and single-vertex selection of W and Z events

body_text.text: Assuming a total inelastic cross section of about 70 mb [29,30], an instantaneous luminosity of 0.17 µb −1 /s corresponds to an average of about one inelastic pileup event.
body_text.section: Pileup rejection and single-vertex selection of W and Z events

body_text.text: The selection efficiency for W and Z events is independent of the instantaneous luminosity.
body_text.section: Pileup rejection and single-vertex selection of W and Z events

body_text.text: However, the chargedparticle multiplicities and the energy depositions in the forward region of the detector (HF calorimeters), and thus especially the LRG signature, are strongly affected by the pileup (i.e., the gap is filled in).
body_text.section: Pileup rejection and single-vertex selection of W and Z events

body_text.text: The effects from pileup events for our analysis have been studied by means of zero-bias data samples where the only requirement was that of beams crossing in the detector.
body_text.section: Pileup rejection and single-vertex selection of W and Z events

body_text.text: Such event samples were collected and analyzed for different instantaneous luminosities and the different periods.
body_text.section: Pileup rejection and single-vertex selection of W and Z events

body_text.text: More details are given in Sect.
body_text.section: Pileup rejection and single-vertex selection of W and Z events
Pileup rejection and single-vertex selection of W and Z events

body_text.text: In order to limit the consequences of pileup, events with more than one vertex are rejected.
body_text.section: Pileup rejection and single-vertex selection of W and Z events

body_text.text: For this analysis a primary vertex, the W(Z)-vertex, is defined as the one which contains the lepton track(s).
body_text.section: Pileup rejection and single-vertex selection of W and Z events

body_text.text: Events with additional vertices, formed by at least three tracks, are rejected.
body_text.section: Pileup rejection and single-vertex selection of W and Z events

body_text.text: Details about the vertex reconstruction algorithm are given in Ref.
body_text.section: Pileup rejection and single-vertex selection of W and Z events
Pileup rejection and single-vertex selection of W and Z events

body_text.text: The W-vertex z-position distribution is roughly Gaussian with a mean of 0.52 cm and a standard deviation of 5.9 cm.
body_text.section: Pileup rejection and single-vertex selection of W and Z events

body_text.text: The observed increase in the number of vertices has been studied using a zero-bias event sample and found to be in agreement with the number of pileup events expected on the basis of the luminosity increase (cf. Table 1).
body_text.section: Pileup rejection and single-vertex selection of W and Z events

body_text.text: Pileup events can be categorized as hard and soft events.
body_text.section: Pileup rejection and single-vertex selection of W and Z events

body_text.text: Hard pp pileup interactions have some detectable charged particles in the central region of the detector and are removed by the multiple-vertex veto.
body_text.section: Pileup rejection and single-vertex selection of W and Z events

body_text.text: The soft component has little or no detectable transverse activity in the central region and does not result in reconstructed vertices.
body_text.section: Pileup rejection and single-vertex selection of W and Z events

body_text.text: The efficiency to reconstruct pileup vertices (including vertex splitting) has been determined from MC simulations of minimum-bias and W → eν events.
body_text.section: Pileup rejection and single-vertex selection of W and Z events

body_text.text: Based on the pileup conditions in the 2010 data, the efficiency to detect pp pileup interactions was found to be essentially constant within ±25 cm along the z direction of the nominal interaction point with an average of about 72%.
body_text.section: Pileup rejection and single-vertex selection of W and Z events

body_text.text: The inefficiency essentially depends only on the amount of soft pileup interactions (e.g., events without detectable charged particles in the central region of the detector) in the MC simulation.
body_text.section: Pileup rejection and single-vertex selection of W and Z events

body_text.text: The reconstruction efficiency for pileup vertices was found to be essentially independent for the different luminosity periods, as long as the vertices were separated by more than 0.1 cm.
body_text.section: Pileup rejection and single-vertex selection of W and Z events

body_text.text: The corresponding inefficiency to detect the merged pileup vertex is estimated to be 3.3%.
body_text.section: Pileup rejection and single-vertex selection of W and Z events

body_text.text: The uncertainties from the remaining soft pileup events on the results presented below are discussed in more detail in Sect.

Pileup rejection and single-vertex selection of W and Z events

body_text.text: The numbers of single-vertex W and Z events are summarized in Table 1.
body_text.section: Pileup rejection and single-vertex selection of W and Z events

body_text.text: The single-vertex event yields, compared to the inclusive event yields, decrease with increasing instantaneous luminosity and are in agreement with the expected numbers of vertices from the simulation, assuming Poisson distributions.

body_text.text: Central charged-particle multiplicity and forward energy flow

The observables used to study the underlying event structure in W and Z events are the charged-particle multiplicity in the central detector, the energy depositions in both HF calorimeters (in the following designated as HF+ and HF− depending on the sign of the corresponding η coverage), and the correlations between them.

body_text.text: In the following, only the distributions for W → ν events are discussed.

body_text.text: Soft pileup events and HF energy distributions

The observed mean energy values in the HF increased by about 10 ± 5 GeV from period I to period II and by about 15 ± 5 GeV from period II to period III (cf. Table 2), both in W → eν and W → μν events.
body_text.section: Soft pileup events and HF energy distributions

body_text.text: This increase of HF energy depositions is interpreted as arising from soft pileup events, not identified by the vertex finder.
body_text.section: Soft pileup events and HF energy distributions

body_text.text: A similar increase of the mean energy deposition in HF is also seen in the MC simulations, when events with and without pileup are compared.
body_text.section: Soft pileup events and HF energy distributions

body_text.text: The properties of such soft pileup events have been studied with the zero-bias data samples, where the only requirement was that of beams crossing in the detector, taken during the different running periods.
body_text.section: Soft pileup events and HF energy distributions

body_text.text: In events from this sample with zero reconstructed vertices, three classes of events can be identified: (1) events with no energy deposition in either HF (hereafter referred to as quasi-elastic pp-scattering), (2) events with zero energy in only one of the HF calorimeters and non-zero energy in the other (soft scattering with a LRG signature), and (3) events with non-zero energy depositions in both HF calorimeters (soft inelastic pp-scattering).
body_text.section: Soft pileup events and HF energy distributions

body_text.text: The contributions of beam-gas events and other beamrelated backgrounds to the HF energy dispositions were studied in randomly triggered events with non-colliding beams and were found to be negligible.
body_text.section: Soft pileup events and HF energy distributions

body_text.text: The relative fraction of quasi-elastic pp-scattering event candidates in the zero-bias samples decreases from about 50% in period I to 20% in period III, while the fraction of soft inelastic events increases from about 15% in period I to 40% in period III.
body_text.section: Soft pileup events and HF energy distributions

body_text.text: The fraction of soft events with a LRG signature of about 40% is roughly constant across the three luminosity periods.
body_text.section: Soft pileup events and HF energy distributions

body_text.text: In conclusion, soft pileup events, not identified by the single-vertex requirement, can have an important effect on the HF energy distributions and on LRG events in particular.
body_text.section: Soft pileup events and HF energy distributions

body_text.text: As discussed below, their contribution is well modeled by the MC simulations.
body_text.section: Soft pileup events and HF energy distributions

body_text.text: Correlations of the forward energy flow and the central charged-particle multiplicity
In the following, the correlation between the central chargedparticle multiplicity and the forward energy flow is measured in the data and compared to MC models.
body_text.section: Correlations of the forward energy flow and the central charged-particle multiplicity

body_text.text: For this study, events with energy depositions in the HF− calorimeter of 20-100 GeV (low), 200-400 GeV (medium), and above 500 GeV (high) are selected.
body_text.section: Correlations of the forward energy flow and the central charged-particle multiplicity

body_text.text: The central chargedparticle multiplicity distributions with track p T thresholds of 1 GeV (for W → eν events) and 0.5 GeV (for W → μν events) are shown in Fig. 3, while the HF+ energy distributions for the three HF− energy intervals are shown in Fig. 4 (for W → eν and W → μν events).
body_text.section: Correlations of the forward energy flow and the central charged-particle multiplicity

body_text.text: The charged-particle multiplicity distributions for the medium HF− energy range (Figs. 3c and 3d) are described reasonably well by the PYTHIA6 D6T and Z2 tunes.
body_text.section: Correlations of the forward energy flow and the central charged-particle multiplicity

body_text.text: The agreement between the data and the D6T tune is poorer when a 1 GeV track p T threshold is applied.
body_text.section: Correlations of the forward energy flow and the central charged-particle multiplicity

body_text.text: For the low HF energy range (Figs. 3a and 3b), the D6T tune fails to describe the charged-particle multiplicity distribution, whereas the Z2 tune is in good agreement with the data, after applying a 0.5 GeV track p T threshold.
body_text.section: Correlations of the forward energy flow and the central charged-particle multiplicity

body_text.text: Finally, when requiring a large HF energy deposition (Figs. 3e and 3f), the Z2 tune provides a good description, whereas the D6T tune overestimates the charged-particle multiplicity.
body_text.section: Correlations of the forward energy flow and the central charged-particle multiplicity

body_text.text: The HF+ distributions for the medium HF− energy interval ( Figs. 4c and 4d) are in better agreement with the predictions of the various tunes than the inclusive HF distributions ( Figs. 2c and 2d).
body_text.section: Correlations of the forward energy flow and the central charged-particle multiplicity

body_text.section: Correlations of the forward energy flow and the central charged-particle multiplicity

body_text.text: Finally, for events with high-energy depositions in HF−, the PYTHIA8 generator, which in the inclusive case under-estimates the rate of events with large HF− energy depositions, provides a good description of the energy distribution in HF+.

body_text.text: Conversely, all other tunes predict more events with large HF+ energy than observed in the data (Figs. 4e  and 4f).

body_text.text: Interpretation of the observed HF energy and charged-particle multiplicity correlations

As seen in the previous section, the energy distributions in the two HF calorimeters and the central charged-particle multiplicities are strongly correlated: large energy depositions in one of the HF calorimeters correspond to large energy depositions in the other HF calorimeter, as well as to an increase in the central charged-particle multiplicity.
body_text.section: Interpretation of the observed HF energy and charged-particle multiplicity correlations

body_text.text: Such correlations are also predicted by the various MC tunes, though with very different strengths.
body_text.section: Interpretation of the observed HF energy and charged-particle multiplicity correlations

body_text.text: Our observations can be summarized as follows:
body_text.section: Interpretation of the observed HF energy and charged-particle multiplicity correlations

body_text.text: D6T tune The inclusive distribution of charged-particle multiplicities, with a minimum p T of 0.5 GeV, is reasonably well described, whereas raising this threshold to 1 GeV leads to an overestimation of the event rate with large multiplicities.
body_text.section: Interpretation of the observed HF energy and charged-particle multiplicity correlations

body_text.text: Furthermore, on average much-larger HF energy depositions are predicted than observed.
body_text.section: Interpretation of the observed HF energy and charged-particle multiplicity correlations

body_text.text: When selecting events with small energy depositions in the HF, the fraction of events in the data is 30-50% larger than predicted by the D6T tune.
body_text.section: Interpretation of the observed HF energy and charged-particle multiplicity correlations

body_text.text: In terms of correlations, the D6T tune provides a reasonable description only for the charged-particle multiplicity in the medium HF− energy interval (track p T threshold of 0.5 GeV) and for HF+ energy distribution corresponding to the low HF− energy bin.
body_text.section: Interpretation of the observed HF energy and charged-particle multiplicity correlations

body_text.text: Z2 tune Overall, the Z2 tune provides a very good description of the inclusive charged-particle multiplicities, but predicts too many events with very low charged-particle multiplicities.
body_text.section: Interpretation of the observed HF energy and charged-particle multiplicity correlations

body_text.text: Concerning the HF energy distributions, too many events with low-energy depositions are predicted.
body_text.section: Interpretation of the observed HF energy and charged-particle multiplicity correlations

body_text.text: The correlations between charged-particle multiplicity and HF− energy are well described.
body_text.section: Interpretation of the observed HF energy and charged-particle multiplicity correlations

body_text.text: The HF+ energy distribution obtained for the low HF− energy interval is badly modeled, with the MC prediction much higher than the data at low energies.
body_text.section: Interpretation of the observed HF energy and charged-particle multiplicity correlations

body_text.text: However, the correlations are well described for the higher HF− energy intervals.
body_text.section: Interpretation of the observed HF energy and charged-particle multiplicity correlations

body_text.text: Pro-Q20 tune This tune provides the best description of the HF energy distributions and the charged-particle multiplicities with the p T > 0.5 GeV threshold.
body_text.section: Interpretation of the observed HF energy and charged-particle multiplicity correlations

body_text.text: However, the inclusive charged-particle multiplicity for the p T > 1.0 GeV threshold is not well described, though still closer to the Fig. 3 Charged-particle multiplicity distributions in the data and from MC simulations with different tunes, for the three HF− energy intervals of

body_text.text: In summary, none of the analyzed MC tunes provides an overall consistent and reasonable description of the inclusive charged-particle multiplicities and the HF energy distributions in the W data sample, as well as correlations between them.

body_text.text: W and Z events with large pesudorapidity gaps
As the next step, the subset of W and Z events with a single primary vertex and a LRG signature was analyzed.
body_text.section: W and Z events with large pesudorapidity gaps

body_text.text: A LRG event was defined by the requirement that none of the calorimeter towers had a measured energy of more than 4 GeV in at least one of the HF calorimeters, corresponding to a pseudorapidity interval of 1.9 units.
body_text.section: W and Z events with large pesudorapidity gaps

body_text.text: This subset of events may be enhanced by a diffractive W/Z production mechanism.
body_text.section: W and Z events with large pesudorapidity gaps

body_text.text: Table 3 shows the observed LRG event yields and their ratio to the number of inclusive W and Z single-vertex events for the three luminosity periods.
body_text.section: W and Z events with large pesudorapidity gaps

body_text.text: This ratio decreases by roughly a factor of 2 to 4 when going from period I to period III.
body_text.section: W and Z events with large pesudorapidity gaps

body_text.text: The decrease can be explained by the HF energy depositions coming from soft pileup events.
body_text.section: W and Z events with large pesudorapidity gaps

body_text.text: As discussed in Sect.
body_text.section: W and Z events with large pesudorapidity gaps

body_text.text: 5.1 (cf. Fig. 2c), adding pileup to the Monte Carlo simulation shifts some of the LRG events to the class of low-energy depositions in the HF.
body_text.section: W and Z events with large pesudorapidity gaps

body_text.text: The inefficiency to detect a vertex in an event with forward energy deposition depends on the instantaneous luminosity and is estimated from zero-bias events (Sect. 5.1).
body_text.section: W and Z events with large pesudorapidity gaps

body_text.text: After correcting the observed number of LRG events in the data for pileup effects, using data, a constant fraction of LRG events, relative to the total number of W and Z events with a single primary vertex, is found for the three instantaneous luminosity periods.
body_text.section: W and Z events with large pesudorapidity gaps

body_text.text: The corrected fraction of LRG events is given in Table 4.
body_text.section: W and Z events with large pesudorapidity gaps

body_text.text: The uncertainties on this correction are small compared to the statistical errors and to the ±10% energy scale uncertainties of the HF calorimeters (for details see [27]).
body_text.section: W and Z events with large pesudorapidity gaps

body_text.text: Indeed, this energy scale variation is the dominant systematic uncertainty for the estimated fraction of LRG events in the data, resulting in a change of about ±26% when varying the tower energy threshold between 3.6 and 4.4 GeV.
body_text.section: W and Z events with large pesudorapidity gaps

body_text.text: Observed number of LRG events

Combining the results obtained with electrons and muons, the percentage of W and Z events with LRG signature is (1.46 ± 0.09 (stat.) ± 0.38 (syst.))% and (1.57 ± 0.25 (stat.) ± 0.42 (syst.))%, respectively.
body_text.section: Observed number of LRG events

body_text.text: In comparison, as can be seen from Figs.
body_text.section: Observed number of LRG events

body_text.text: 2 and 5, the fraction of W LRG events predicted with the PYTHIA6 Z2 and Pro-Q20 and the PYTHIA8 2C tunes are larger than observed in the data.
body_text.section: Observed number of LRG events

body_text.text: In contrast, for the D6T tune the number of LRG events is smaller than in the data.
body_text.section: Observed number of LRG events

body_text.text: 6.2 Jet activity in W/Z events with a LRG signature and search for exclusive W/Z production A further subset of W and Z events are those that show some jet activity, using the particle-flow algorithm with a cone size of 0.5.
body_text.section: Observed number of LRG events

body_text.text: We find (11.1 ± 0.2)% of the selected W and Z events with a single vertex contain at least one reconstructed jet with a transverse momentum above 30 GeV and |η| < 2.5.
body_text.section: Observed number of LRG events

body_text.text: Taking the subsample of 100 identified W → eν events with a LRG signature, 8 events are found with one or more jets above a 30 GeV threshold.
body_text.section: Observed number of LRG events

body_text.text: The corresponding numbers for the muon channel are 145 identified LRG events and 8 of them with at least one jet.
body_text.section: Observed number of LRG events

body_text.text: Thus, we find that (6.5 ± 1.6)% of the LRG events have jet activity, which is smaller (but still consistent) with the fraction of events with jets observed in the inclusive W sample.
body_text.section: Observed number of LRG events

body_text.text: No other particular features of the events with jet activities, when compared to the MC simulations, are observed.
body_text.section: Observed number of LRG events

body_text.text: Another potentially interesting class of LRG events consists of W and Z events with essentially no activity besides that from the vector-boson decays.
body_text.section: Observed number of LRG events

body_text.text: Such candidate exclusive events are selected with the requirement that both HF calorimeters fulfill the LRG condition and that no particleflow object besides the lepton(s) is reconstructed in the central detector, above a transverse momentum threshold of 0.5 GeV.
body_text.section: Observed number of LRG events

body_text.text: For the electron selection no such events are found.
body_text.section: Observed number of LRG events

body_text.text: In the muon case, 2 W and 2 Z event candidates with zero energy in both HF calorimeters are found.
body_text.section: Observed number of LRG events

body_text.text: All four events have some reconstructed tracks in the central detector.
body_text.section: Observed number of LRG events

body_text.text: The number of observed events is consistent with expected number of non-exclusive W and Z events predicted from the MC simulations.
body_text.section: Observed number of LRG events

body_text.text: Size of the pseudorapidity gap and central gaps
For the study of events with large pseudorapidity gaps an interesting parameter is how far the size of the gap extends into the central detector.
body_text.section: Size of the pseudorapidity gap and central gaps

body_text.text: One might intuitively expect that the ratio of diffractive signal events compared to background from multiplicity fluctuations, would become larger when the gap size increases into the central detector.
body_text.section: Size of the pseudorapidity gap and central gaps

body_text.text: This intuitive view is confirmed when comparing diffractive W events simulated with POMPYT, where the decrease in event yields with increasing gap size is much smaller than in the different nondiffractive MC models.
body_text.section: Size of the pseudorapidity gap and central gaps

body_text.text: Obviously, the definition of the gap is ambiguous, as the meaning of zero activity or zero energy depositions depends on the experimental criteria for the detection of particles in the data and in the MC simulation.
body_text.section: Size of the pseudorapidity gap and central gaps

body_text.text: For this study the size of the pseudorapidity gap was determined by using particle-flow objects with a minimum energy of 1.5 GeV for |η| < 1.5 (barrel), 2 GeV for 1.5 < |η| < 2.85 (endcaps), and 4 GeV for |η| > 2.85 (HF calorimeters).
body_text.section: Size of the pseudorapidity gap and central gaps

body_text.text: For charged particle-flow candidates a minimum transverse momentum of 0.5 GeV was required.
body_text.section: Size of the pseudorapidity gap and central gaps

body_text.text: The largest (η max ) and smallest (η min ) observed pseudorapidity values of the particles are used to determine the gap size between the maximum (minimum) η coverage of the experiment and the nearest detected particle on each side.
body_text.section: Size of the pseudorapidity gap and central gaps

body_text.text: In order to combine both hemispheres, we defineη as the minimum of η max and −η min .
body_text.section: Size of the pseudorapidity gap and central gaps

body_text.text: The size of the pseudorapidity gap is then η 4.9 gap = 4.9 −η, where 4.9 is the largest η value covered by the HF.
body_text.section: Size of the pseudorapidity gap and central gaps

body_text.text: Figures 6a and 6b show theη distribution in the data and MC simulation with different tunes, for the W decays to electrons and muons, respectively.
body_text.section: Size of the pseudorapidity gap and central gaps

body_text.text: The fraction of events with pseudorapidity gaps decreases rapidly when the gap size increases.
body_text.section: Size of the pseudorapidity gap and central gaps

body_text.text: A statistically significant excess of events at η values smaller than 3 is observed, compared to the predictions of the non-diffractive model implemented in PYTHIA6, tune D6T.
body_text.section: Size of the pseudorapidity gap and central gaps

body_text.text: However, the fraction of events with very large gaps and without a diffractive component in the PYTHIA6 Z2, Pro-Q20, and PYTHIA8 2C tunes and up to the largest observed gap size is larger than in the data.

body_text.text: In comparison, 0.8, 3.5, and 2.2 such events are expected from the non-diffractive MC simulation based on the PYTHIA6 D6T, Z2, and Pro-Q20 tunes, respectively.

body_text.text: Charged-particle multiplicity and forward energy distributions in LRG events
The charged-particle multiplicity distribution in LRG events, from combining the W events in the electron and muon channels, is shown in Fig. 7a for a minimum track p T of 0.5 GeV.
body_text.section: Charged-particle multiplicity and forward energy distributions in LRG events

body_text.text: A slight excess of events with large chargedparticle multiplicities is found in the data, compared to the various non diffractive MC tunes.
body_text.section: Charged-particle multiplicity and forward energy distributions in LRG events

body_text.text: However, overall the track p T spectrum is well described.
body_text.section: Charged-particle multiplicity and forward energy distributions in LRG events

body_text.text: The number of LRG events with 20 and more tracks, combining the electron and muon channels, is 33 in the data.
body_text.section: Charged-particle multiplicity and forward energy distributions in LRG events

body_text.text: Only 13 (19) events with more than 20 tracks are expected from the D6T (Z2) tunes.
body_text.section: Charged-particle multiplicity and forward energy distributions in LRG events

body_text.text: A similar, but statistically less significant, excess of events with multiplicities larger than predicted by the different tunes is also observed when a track threshold of p T > 1.0 GeV is required.
body_text.section: Charged-particle multiplicity and forward energy distributions in LRG events

body_text.text: The POMPYT diffractive model, which does not include multi-parton interactions, predicts even smaller chargedparticle multiplicities.
body_text.section: Charged-particle multiplicity and forward energy distributions in LRG events

body_text.text: However, the observed excess of events with relatively large charged-particle multiplicities in LRG events could be an indication of a diffractive component in the multi-parton interactions, as depicted in Figs. 1c  and 1f.

body_text.text: In the data, we find 2 events with no towers above the energy threshold of 4 GeV in either HF calorimeters, in agreement with the expectation from the D6T tune.

body_text.text: The data show that charged leptons from W decays are found more often in the hemisphere opposite to the gap.
body_text.section: Charged-particle multiplicity and forward energy distributions in LRG events

body_text.text: Combining the electron and muon channels, 147 events are found with the charged lepton in the hemisphere opposite to the gap and 96 events with the lepton in the same hemisphere.
body_text.section: Charged-particle multiplicity and forward energy distributions in LRG events

body_text.text: Defining an asymmetry as the ratio of the difference between the numbers of LRG events in each hemisphere and the sum, the corresponding asymmetry is (−21.0 ± 6.4)%.
body_text.section: Charged-particle multiplicity and forward energy distributions in LRG events

body_text.text: In the case of Z candidates (the rapidity of the Z is used) with a LRG signature, 24 (16) events are in the opposite (same) hemisphere as the gap, resulting in an asymmetry of (−20 ± 16)%.
body_text.section: Charged-particle multiplicity and forward energy distributions in LRG events

body_text.text: In comparison, the various non-diffractive MC tunes predict a symmetric lepton pseudorapidity distribution in LRG events.
body_text.section: Charged-particle multiplicity and forward energy distributions in LRG events

body_text.text: On the other hand, events generated with the POMPYT generator, based on a diffractive production model, exhibit a strong asymmetry.
body_text.section: Charged-particle multiplicity and forward energy distributions in LRG events

body_text.text: This can be explained in terms of diffractive PDFs, which peak at smaller x (the parton momentum divided by the proton momentum) than the conventional proton PDFs.
body_text.section: Charged-particle multiplicity and forward energy distributions in LRG events

body_text.text: The produced W(Z) is thus boosted in the direction of the parton that had the larger x.
body_text.section: Charged-particle multiplicity and forward energy distributions in LRG events

body_text.text: This is typically the direction of the dissociated proton, i.e., opposite to the gap.
body_text.section: Charged-particle multiplicity and forward energy distributions in LRG events

body_text.text: The signed lepton pseudorapidity distribution in the data is fit to the predictions from the diffractive POMPYT and the non-diffractive PYTHIA event generators, with the relative fraction of the two as the free parameter.
body_text.section: Charged-particle multiplicity and forward energy distributions in LRG events

body_text.text: The fit results in a fraction of diffractive events in the LRG sample of (50.0 ± 9.3 (stat.) ± 5.2 (syst.))%, assuming the model of diffraction implemented in POMPYT and using the PYTHIA6 Pro-Q20 for the simulation of non-diffractive events.
body_text.section: Charged-particle multiplicity and forward energy distributions in LRG events

body_text.text: The fit results are shown in Fig. 8.
body_text.section: Charged-particle multiplicity and forward energy distributions in LRG events

body_text.text: The fits using the combination of POMPYT with other tunes give similar results, and only the non-diffractive contribution from the other tunes is shown in Fig. 8.
body_text.section: Charged-particle multiplicity and forward energy distributions in LRG events

body_text.text: The systematic uncertainty of 5.2% has been determined from the 10% HF energy scale variations and from the fits with the different tunes, using the maximal and minimal fractions obtained from the different fits.

body_text.text: Hemisphere correlations between the gap and the W (Z) boson
The asymmetry in the signed η distribution for non-LRG events is found to decrease when the forward energy deposition increases.
body_text.section: Hemisphere correlations between the gap and the W (Z) boson

body_text.text: For example, for HF energy depositions in the intervals 20-100 GeV, 200-400 GeV, and >500 GeV, the asymmetry is (−3.5±1.1)%, (−2.7±1.0)%, and (0.9 ± 2.3)%.
body_text.section: Hemisphere correlations between the gap and the W (Z) boson

body_text.text: The small residual asymmetry in events with low HF energy depositions is insignificant in comparison to the one in LRG events.
body_text.section: Hemisphere correlations between the gap and the W (Z) boson

body_text.text: However, this could be explained by the presence of a small fraction of diffractively produced W bosons events in which the LRG signature is destroyed by the accompanying multi-parton interaction or by the undetected pileup component.
body_text.section: Hemisphere correlations between the gap and the W (Z) boson

body_text.text: For higher energy depositions in the forward region, the asymmetry vanishes.
body_text.section: Hemisphere correlations between the gap and the W (Z) boson

body_text.text: Conclusions

Central charged-particle multiplicities, forward energy flow, and correlations between them have been studied in W and Z events, identified by the vector-boson decays to electrons and muons, using the 2010 data sample of pp collisions at 7 TeV, corresponding to an integrated luminosity of 36 pb −1 .
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: None of the studied MC tunes provides simultaneously a satisfactory description of the charged-particle multiplicity in the central pseudorapidity region (|η| < 2.5) and the forward energy flow (3 < |η| < 4.9).
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: The PYTHIA6 Z2 and PYTHIA8 2C tunes give a reasonable description of the central charged-particle multiplicity, but predict too many events with relatively low-energy depositions in the forward calorimeters.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: The PYTHIA6 D6T tune predicts too many events with high charged-particle multiplicities, too few events with low-energy depositions, and too many events with very large energy depositions in the forward calorimeters.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: The Pro-Q20 tune provides the best description of the forward energy distribution and a good description of the charged-particle multiplicity, when a track p T threshold of 0.5 GeV is applied.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: However, the charged-particle multiplicity with p T > 1.0 GeV is not well described, though the prediction is closer to the data than that for the D6T tune.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: Strong positive correlations between the energy measured in the two forward calorimeters (i.e. at positive and negative rapidities) and the charged-particle multiplicity are observed in the data and in Monte Carlo models.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: However, the correlations in the various MC tunes are different from those seen in the data.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: As far as the LRG events are concerned, the following observations can be made:
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: -Out of a sample of about 40 000 W and Z events, almost 300 events with a LRG signature are found.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: According to the POMPYT model of diffractive W production, such events can be interpreted as diffractive.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: However, while the observed fraction of such events is significantly larger than predicted with the non-diffractive PYTHIA6 D6T tune, it is smaller than expected from the PYTHIA6 Z2, Pro-Q20, and PYTHIA8 2C tunes.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: Thus, no conclusions can be drawn from the presence of LRG events.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: -The central charged-particle multiplicity in these events is somewhat larger than predicted by the various models.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: -The HF energy distribution opposite to the gap peaks at much smaller values than in the inclusive events, and is reasonably well described by the MC generators.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: -A large asymmetry is observed between the number of events with the charged lepton (from the W decay) in the opposite and with it in the same hemisphere as the pseudorapidity gap.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: Such an asymmetry is predicted by POMPYT, in contrast to the various non-diffractive PYTHIA MC tunes.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: When fitting the observed asymmetry in LRG events with an admixture of diffractive (POMPYT) and non-diffractive (PYTHIA) events, the diffractive component is determined to be (50.0 ± 9.3 (stat.) ± 5.2 (syst.))%, thus providing the first evidence for diffractive W production at the LHC.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: A comparable, but statistically less significant asymmetry is seen in Z events with large pseudorapidity gaps.
body_text.section: Conclusions
